Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2009 06:00AM happy29 wrote: Hi- I can not comment on Lymphedema because I do not know enough but I think Dr Love's book has helped me through a lot! She is clear through out the book that they are still learning more about breast cancer . many aspects are still in infancy stages- such as genetic testing.  I am glad that someone cares enough to take their time and energy to try and make sense of this . Even if we do not agree with her, we can not just dismiss all the good she has done.She has done much research- AND she continues to write updated versions, which include new studies and new info.I would be worried if she were still a surgeon and wonder how she could have the time to do evrything. I wish she or someone else had all the answers....They just don't................. Hopefully Dr Love or someone else will find all the answers soon. Happy
Posts.Title: Susan Love proclaims no need for lymphedema risk reductions kira TammyLou

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2009 05:21AM happy29 wrote: Breast fed their child the day after???  whew -that women is so in her own world. Is this a not so funny sit com? lol
Posts.Title: Cannot believe what the neighbor said... Ang7 Shanagirl

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2009 11:32AM happy29 wrote: I am so sorry to hear your story. How unfair and I can not imagine the helplessness you must have felt as well as anyone that was with you (loved ones)  I had masetctomy with flap reconstruction. SO I have breast pain and donor site pain. I was on a IV and they used Dilaudin. I had them use half of what was perscribed but they gave my dosage to me sooner than would have if I used full amount. This worked for me. Unfortunately, I can not remember what the dose was- I want to say 1 mg and I used .5. That was for three days- then I went to percocet-which I am still using as needed four weeks later.  I am glad you will discuss this with your BS. You may be experiencing some post traumatic stress symptoms. No surprise this woul dhit you a few weeks after the surgery. Now that things are settling down for me- I aklso am remembering some not so pleasant things when I was in hospital. Nothing like yours but I think when our minds are outof crisis mode- Is when it all can "hit"us.
Posts.Title: Pain medicine for mastectomy--survey tracyanne tracyanne

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2009 03:45PM happy29 wrote: I had two lumpectomies with DCIS and neither could get clean margins. I was told that my BS would try a third time but I would need plastic surgery and be unhappy with the results cosmetically- IF he got clean margins. I went for a mastectomy (bilateral) I went out of state with a PS -therefore had a new Breast surgeon that did my mastectomy. HE said he has yet to see after one lumpectomy without clean margins turn out well when anyone goes down the road with further lumpectomies.  My mastectomy breast patholgy report showed that I made a good decisions because another lumpectomy would NOT have gotten clean margins. My Dcis was 6mm in my lobular. also my left breasthad much fluid in it from the two lumpectomies and my BS said it would have deflated or collapsed with in the year when my fluid would have disolved. It is a hard decision....  Not sure if this helps...  Do you have DCIS?
Posts.Title: Surgery Again or what? cabmom Lilah

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2009 04:38PM happy29 wrote: Hi jll18,  I am sorry that you are feeling this way about yourself :(   Our feelings do not have to make sense but all your feelings are valid.  You have been through a whirl wind with big decision and now are having complications. BC stinks in so many ways .   I think you are ceratinly in the right place by being on BCO (breastcancer.org)  here you will find so many women that have similar feelings and helps us get through this horrible disease.  You may even laugh at times :) Also try posting questions in breast reconstruction forum. This way maybe the next surgery can get it right.  Good Luck to you :)

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2009 07:48PM happy29 wrote: I have DCIS in left breast and BS is having trouble getting clean margins. I am considering Bilat because after current cancer is treatde- chance of another cancer  in either breast is increased so Tamoxifen is recommended.  I hate MRI's. I feel in order to get this "monkey off my back" the best I can is to go for both.  I feel we all have such different difficult personal decisions to make. It stinks. I really like my breasts. I would get rid of both thighs in a minute if the cancer was there. lol  Good luck to you:)
Posts.Title: Prophylactic bilateral mx simmonba CAROLMARIE427

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2010 09:10PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 07:27PM by happy29 I am DREADING my next MRI. It is causing me so much anxiety.I am Horribly claustrophobic and the LOUD noises make it worse. 1st MRI- I left 2 minutes into it- I literally said you will NOT see me again. I went straight for the biopsy  I was diagnosed and my Doctor said I NEEDED an MRI to check other breast. So I ate my words and I took 3 valium and 2 ativan- It was better and doable but I feel panic just thinking about it. My Doctor said I have until December for my next MRI . I asked for total sedation and they said that you need an anestesiologist there and so it was not possible. I need what you did.  I have heard this Versed can cause adverse effects.  I would love some ":twilight" sedation.Where can I find a place that will do it this way? Happy
Posts.Title: MRI when claustrophobic Sunmuffin happy29

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2009 08:12PM happy29 wrote: Hello, I had nipple discharge - a mammogram  and ultrsound showed nothing. I tried an  open MRI and could NOT do it after fifteen minutes- it was horrible. I had an awful Panic attack. the reality was that an MRI can not diagnos whether it is cancerous .I needed a biopsy anyway. I had one and it showed DCIS-then Doctor wanted me to try for another MRI to see if anything was happening in right breast. I got through it second time around with 6 valium and an ativan. YES someone must drive you. After two lumpectomies and unable to get clean margins- I went for bilateral mastectomy -one breast was prophylactic to never need yearly MRI's and tamoxifen. So the original MRI would have just helped him have a better idea where to do biopsy... so maybe you do not really need one.... Try not to worry because it may be for no reason. Many changes in the breast are Benign!!!!!  Good luck!
Posts.Title: CHICKEND OUT ON MRI gegfl SuziQ422

Posts.Content: happy29 wrote: Hello I am 38 and miscarried two weeks before I was diagnosed. I have two healthy daughters. I had DCIS and was ER+. I have significant family history. I am wondering if anyone has had chidren after after a double Mx and how long they waited. I am only 3 weeks post op and I may have too much time on my hands to be thinking of this so soon. I also think some family members may disapprove of me being pregnant after BC. Not sure what to do...... if anything. I know there are no guarantees and I do not want to put my life in High risk of a recurrance. Has anyone else experienced this dilema? Posts.Title: Pregnancy after double Mastectomy? happy29 happy29

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2009 12:16PM happy29 wrote: Nordy, Thank you for sharing your awesome story and thank you for the information! I can not imagine having a 3 month old and enduring chemo! how scary! your family sounds really special  It is nice to hear your story and how life moves on after all this BC issues that fill our minds for so long. And now your story goes to reconstruction and then back to raising your children and spending time with your family.  Something about it is almost appealing to know how much every day must mean to all of us.  Not to get too mushy- but I know after this (and I did not endure chemo) I feel closer to God and much more grateful to all the Important things in life -like my family and children.  Anyway, I appreciate your inspiring story and also the BCO web page . and you are SO right - this is a decision between my and DH. Thanks for saying that.  Happy
